ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

POSTAL SERVICE AUTOMATION
(Cost savings)


    1. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Communications and Information Technology (a) what will be the cost savings in postal operations as a result of automated mailing processing and whether such savings will be passed on to the public and business community in the form of lower postage rates as a real incentive to encourage automation; and (b) whether his Ministry will provide a comparison of postage rates in Singapore, Malaysia and Brunei as well as a detailed explanation on the recent increases in international postage rates despite the cost savings through automation.

    The Minister of State for Communications and Information Technology (Mr Lim Swee Say) (for the Minister for Communications and Information Technology): Mr Speaker, Sir, postal rates were revised on 1st November this year, five years after the last revision in 1995. During this period, the cost of mail processing and delivery has continued to rise due to increases in wage costs and administration costs. However, with automation and computerisation, SingPost is able to increase labour productivity and offset some of these cost increases.

    In the recent revision, it has kept the rates for domestic standard mail, which accounts for more than 90% of domestic total volume, largely unchanged. The postage rate was raised only for standard mails in the 40-50 grams weight step, which comprises less than 0.5% of all standard mails.

    Mr Tay asked for comparison for postage rates in Singapore, Malaysia and Brunei. Sir, for the basic 20 grams standard size mail, our rate is 0.22 cents. This is higher than 0.14 cents in Brunei and 0.22 cents in Malaysia, due to higher wage structure in Singapore. If we were to compare our rates with economies of

Column: 1113

similar wage structure, SingPost's rate of 0.22 cents is lower than 0.29 cents in Hong Kong and 0.28 cents in Taiwan. So on balance, IDA's price control framework does ensure that our postal rates are competitive.

    Mr Tay also asked about international mail rates. The two major cost components are operating costs and payment to destination countries. I wish to point out that operating costs account for only 38% of the total cost. The remaining 62% are payments to destination countries. The rates of payment are determined by an International Accounting System established by the Universal Postal Union, and the payments are beyond the control of SingPost. The recent hike in international postal rates is to allow SingPost to recover part of the increase in the rates of payment to destination countries.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan (Nominated Member): Sir, is the Minister aware that the abolition of second-class postage for printed materials by SingPost has resulted in a substantial increase in the postal cost for business magazines and newsletters alike, which can no longer be posted at a cheaper second-class mail? The increase of such postal rates could be as high as 67% for local mail and over 100% for overseas mail. This is definitely not a pro-business approach and I wonder whether the Minister could explain this.

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I mentioned earlier, in terms of international mail, more than 60% of the costs are really beyond the control of SingPost. So the increase in international mail rates is really a cost increase that we have no choice but to bear. As far as domestic mail is concerned, the priority is to encourage automation. For example, if companies or individuals, in particular companies, are able to take advantage of the incentive schemes offered by SingPost, such as the domestic mail bulk scheme, ie, they lodge their letters in a machineable bar-coded and pre-sorted manner, they can enjoy a substantial discount from SingPost. So

Column: 1114

my suggestion is for companies, big and small, to take full advantage of the efficiency that can be achieved through automation. In this way, we can have a win-win situation between SingPost and the users.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Is the Minister aware that, despite the high rates that Singapore charges, in this age today, it sometimes takes four or five days for letters to reach the addressee in Singapore itself?

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, for the ordinary letters mailed in Singapore, IDA does not just control the rates. It also imposes performance indicators on SingPost. For example, a certain percentage of the mail would have to be delivered within the same day and a certain percentage will have to be delivered by the next day. In the example cited by the Member regarding the delay of four to five days, if I could have the information, I would be happy to look into it. To the best of our knowledge, almost 100% of mails are either delivered on the same day or by the next day. But, as I said, I would be happy to have the information so that we can look into this particular incident and see how we can get SingPost to improve on its performance.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Minister saying that I should send to him every letter that I have received three or four days after its posting? If he wants me to do that, I will flood him with them.

    Mr Lim Swee Say: No, Sir. This is not what I meant. What I meant is that we are not aware that there are many letters, as mentioned by the Member, being delayed in the mail for three to four days. That is why I am asking for the feedback. If it is indeed true that most of the letters sent to you ---

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I will flood you with them!

    Mr Lim Swee Say: I would be happy to look into that.

WATER CONTAMINATION
(Preventive measures)


    2. Mr Ang Mong Seng asked the Minister for National Development (a) what measures are being taken to prevent a recurrence of the water contamination problem as had occurred in Bukit Timah Plaza and Chuan Park Condominium; and (b) whether the roles and responsibilities of management agents and management corporations in the Land Titles (Strata) Act are clearly defined.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee) (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, there are two parts to this question. On the first part, at the Parliamentary session on 9th October 2000, Mr Tang Guan Seng, Senior Parliamentary Secretary (Trade and Industry), has outlined the measures taken by the Public Utilities Board (PUB), together with the Ministry of the Environment (ENV), to prevent a recurrence of the water contamination problem. If the Member has more questions, he might wish to direct a question to MTI. Or else, he might want to look up the Hansard.

    On part (b), on the roles and responsibilities of the management corporations (MCs), these are clearly spelt out in the Land Titles (Strata) Act.

    Amongst other things, the management corporation has the duty to properly manage, maintain and keep the common property in a state of good and serviceable repair, keep proper records and books of account and insure the property.

    Sir, under the Act, the MC may appoint a managing agent (MA) and, by a written instrument, delegates its powers, duties and functions to the MA. Where the MC has delegated the performance of a duty to the MA, the Act provides that the MA shall be liable for any contravention of the provisions of the Act in respect of the delegated duty. So the key words are "delegated duty".

    The MC will have to decide for itself the duties to be delegated to the MA, and the

Column: 1116

contractual terms for the appointment. If the MA did not perform, the MC may remove the MA from office. And like any other commercial arrangements, the MC may also seek the appropriate legal remedies if it can establish a breach of contract or negligence on the part of the managing agent.

    Sir, where there are provisions in the Land Titles (Strata) Act, which proved to be inadequate, the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) would initiate and recommend amendments to the Act at the appropriate time.

    Mr Ang Mong Seng (Bukit Gombak): Sir, can I ask two questions? Firstly, at the moment, since the MA's contract is usually for only one year, will the Ministry consider giving a longer contract for the MA to manage private condominiums? Secondly, water tanks. Does the Ministry have special programmes to ensure that MAs check the water tanks within a specific time?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: The details of the terms of a contract are between the MC and the MA. So if the MC wants to award the contract for more than one year, it is up to the MC. Whether the Ministry looks after the water tank safety, the answer is really no, because the Building and Construction Authority is the authority on building as far as structural integrity is concerned. Water contamination problems are actually under the purview of MTI and the Ministry of the Environment. But just to give the background, after the Bukit Timah Plaza incident, MTI and ENV have instructed all MCs to look at their sanitary pipes and to repair these pipes if they are corrugated and to also check their water tanks. They have found that the Bukit Timah Plaza incident was an isolated problem. But, nonetheless, the problem has been fixed.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary if he would say that the two cases cited are actually of a very different nature and whether the real cause of contamination in the Chuan Park case has been established?

Column: 1117



    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: I am not aware of the details of the Chuan Park case. As far as I know, the Chuan Park case was not a serious problem because they had found some kerosene contaminants in the water tank. But the kerosene contaminants were small and minuscule and did not affect human health.

PERFORMANCE OF PLAY "TALAQ"
(Ban)


    3. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will give the reasons why the Public Entertainment Licensing Unit has refused the application for the play "Talaq".

    4. Mr Simon S. C. Tay asked the Minister for Home Affairs why the Government banned the performance of the play "Talaq" by theatre group Agni Koothu at short notice despite the recommendation of the National Arts Council that it be allowed.

    5. Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin asked the Minister for Home Affairs what were the legal grounds under which the performance of the play "Talaq" was disallowed.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, may I take Question Nos. 3, 4 and 5 together as they are related?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Thank you, Sir. The Police's Public Entertainment Licensing Unit (PELU) issues licences for public entertainment and meetings, such as plays, operas, variety acts, music performances and talks under the Public Entertainments Act. In deciding whether or not to grant a licence, PELU may consult the relevant authorities and, amongst other factors, PELU takes into account law and order considerations, including racial and religious sensitivities that may be evoked.

Column: 1118



    Sir, "Talaq", which explores marital violence and rape in the Indian Muslim community, was first performed in Tamil by the Agni Kootthu theatre group in December 1998, and twice in February 1999. In assessing applications made in respect of those performances, PELU sought the National Arts Council's (NAC) views. NAC recommended approval. Hence, PELU approved the licences for the performances. However, following the February 1999 performances, both NAC and PELU received adverse feedback that the play was offensive and misrepresented the Indian Muslim community and Islam.

    Thus, when Ms Thenmoli, the president of Agni Kootthu, applied to PELU on 19th September 2000 for "Talaq" to be staged in Malay and English on 28th and 29th October 2000 respectively, PELU sought the views of NAC. NAC advised PELU to seek the views of Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS), as the play had attracted complaints previously. MUIS informed PELU that they had received objections to the play and recommended that PELU turn down the application. When NAC learnt of this, NAC decided to organise a preview of the play on 16th October 2000. However, Ms Thenmoli at first refused to hold the preview on the grounds that there were representatives from the South Indian Jamiathul Ulama (SIJU) on the preview panel. PELU therefore could not grant the licence for the performances. Ms Thenmoli subsequently changed her mind and agreed to a preview, which was held on 23rd October 2000. Representatives from MUIS, SIJU, Agni Kootthu and PELU were invited.

    Sir, the following day, NAC and the Drama Review Committee (DRC) recommended to PELU that the staging of the play could be allowed, but subject to the removal of certain references to Islam and the announcement before the commencement of each performance and in all publicity materials that "although the play is based on the experiences of an individual, it is not intended to reflect on or defame the Indian Muslim community at large". In giving its recommendations, NAC also stated that ultimately it was

Column: 1119

PELU's prerogative if it wished to place greater weight on MUIS' views.

    Sir, MUIS had strongly objected to the play as it contained Quranic references and religious connotations that might give the audience a wrong impression of Islam. In view of the NAC and DRC's recommendation, PELU sought MUIS' views on whether NAC's proposed conditions were adequate. MUIS replied that the conditions would not adequately address the objections raised by them, and reiterated their earlier strong objections to the play. After taking into consideration NAC's and MUIS' views, PELU turned down the application, as empowered under section 13 of the Public Entertainments Act. PELU conveyed its decision to Ms Thenmoli on 25th October 2000, two days after the preview.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore encourages artistic expression and creativity. But artistic works must respect religious sensitivities in multi-racial and multi-religious Singapore. Artistes should be mindful of our social realities and avoid creating racial or religious tensions, as they too have a responsible role to play in helping to preserve religious and racial harmony in Singapore.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I, first of all, say I see that the overworked Minister of State is again asked to answer all these questions whilst the Minister is here. But that is a matter for them.

    But may I ask the poor overworked Minister of State, do I understand that the objections were first raised by some Indian Muslim men or an association representing them?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I do not know whether the Member heard my answer, but there were earlier performances in 1998 and 1999 in Tamil, and objections were raised.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: By whom?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: By two groups - SIJU and the Federation of

Column: 1120

Indian Muslims. These were not just individuals but complaints from the members of these two groups.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Were there any complaints from any women's organisations?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Not that I know of. I do not think there were complaints from women's organisations.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister of State or his Ministry make public the objections by MUIS setting out how it offends the Muslim religion or the Koran?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: That is part of the decision-making process. I do not think it is up to PELU to disclose all these grounds. In fact, 11 specific grounds were given, on which the view was formed that there were references to Quranic verses and also religious connotations which would give a wrong impression of Islam. Here, because the performances were in Malay and English - unlike the earlier performances which were in Tamil where probably the audience would be a more limited one - there will be larger audiences. So this will lead possibly to people of other races having the wrong impression of Islam, having perhaps an erroneous and lower impression of Islam than what it actually is, and this may lead to misunderstanding amongst the races.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Why was MUIS not told that they were at liberty, if they thought there were wrong interpretations of the Koran or anything else, that they could come out publicly with their statement and so let us have the debate open, instead of all being decided by the "Commissar"?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, it is up to MUIS if it wants to disclose the reasons, but in so far as the process is concerned, PELU has the powers and the discretion, and it has exercised it objectively and correctly. I think that is the important point - taking all views into consideration.

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): First, a point of clarification. I believe the

Column: 1121

first performances of the play in Tamil were subtitled in English, so they did in fact reach a wider audience than just the Tamil community. In fact, I think, quite a few English-speaking were there in the audience and understood the play.

    Secondly, all of us here fully understand that we live in a multi-racial society and that we are very sensitive about not offending all our various communities with their different religious beliefs. But there is also a danger of ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. Can I ask the Member to ask her question?

    Dr Jennifer Lee: Yes. How do we guard against being overly sensitive so that we are forever caught in a mind of not moving ahead when possibly we are overly sensitive to the sensibilities of certain communities? I have read the play and the context of it is very largely domestic violence.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Can I remind the Member that you are not to make statements during Question time.

    Dr Jennifer Lee: Yes, Sir.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I thank the Nominated Member of Parliament for the clarification. But I think we can still see a difference between looking at a play in Tamil and then reading the English subtitles and the actual play being performed in English, because for a start, I think the audience mix will be vastly different and moreover, the impact will be vastly different.

    Yesterday we talked about whether PELU should be the authority for arts performances. In the arts, some will argue that because of the need to balance artistic merit and also the desire of artistes to express themselves and try new things and, on the other hand, the need to ensure that some of these sensitivities we talk about are observed, we have asked PELU to look at it, do a review, and the Ministry will also be in consultation with MITA to see who should be that one-stop agency.

Column: 1122



    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister of State: does he not think seriously that this case affords the best grounds for setting up an appeals board consisting of distinguished, respectable citizens to decide on these questions?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Mr Jeyaretnam missed the debate yesterday. I think we talked about it at length. He was not here. He asked many questions. I answered him and corrected some of his misperceptions. This point was indeed addressed and this review will look at whether or not panels need to be set up.

MOTORCYCLISTS RIDING AND PARKING ON PEDESTRIAN PAVEMENTS

(Action by police)


    6. Mr Goh Chong Chia asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the Police will consider taking action against motorcyclists who have been riding and parking on pedestrian pavements in the Central Area as this poses a threat to the safety of pedestrians.

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee (for the Minister for Home Affairs): The answer is yes. Traffic Police takes a serious view of motorcyclists who ride and park on pedestrian pavements. Such inconsiderate acts cause obstruction and pose a danger to pedestrians. Motorcyclists who park or ride on pedestrian pavements can be fined $70. Traffic Police has been and will continue to take enforcement action against errant motorcyclists.

    Mr Goh Chong Chia (Nominated Member): Sir, obviously, these motorcyclists are people who are short-term delivery boys. Is there a possibility of providing short-term parking?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, there are sufficient parking lots for motorcyclists in the CBD. I have been told that there are currently at least 1,200 URA motorcyclist lots provided in the CBD. So I think it is better for them to time their journeys so that they do not park illegally. I think the very nature of his question suggests that it

Column: 1123

is dangerous for them to do so. So I say it is better for them to time their journey and park where they can legally do so.

ALEXANDRA HOSPITAL AND SAF NCO CLUBHOUSE ALONG BEACH ROAD

(Preservation)


    7. Mr Ong Kian Min asked the Minister for Information and the Arts whether the Alexandra Hospital and the SAF NCO Clubhouse along Beach Road have been placed on the list of buildings considered to be "Gazetted Monuments" by the Preservation and Monuments Board affording these buildings a level of protection and, if not, whether his Ministry will consider doing so as these buildings are of great historical significance and worthy of preservation.

    The Minister for Information and the Arts (Mr Lee Yock Suan): The Preservation of Monuments Board (PMB) and the National Heritage Board (NHB) have done some research on Alexandra Hospital and the SAF NCO Clubhouse.

    During the war, on 14th and 15th February 1942, Japanese soldiers massacred an estimated 200 staff and patients of Alexandra Hospital. The hospital and NHB have already put up a plaque to mark the history of the building. PMB is studying the historical and architectural significance of Alexandra Hospital building to see if it qualifies under current guidelines to be gazetted as a national monument.

    The SAF NCO Clubhouse was built as a clubhouse in 1951 by the British for their servicemen. When the British withdrew in 1969, the building was handed over to the Singapore Government. It became the SAF NCO Clubhouse in 1974. From PMB's research, this building does not have sufficient historical significance to qualify as a national monument. NHB will consider installing a plaque on the history of the building at the Club.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan: May I ask the Minister what are the other criteria

Column: 1124

adopted by PMB, apart from the historical value, such as age and condition of the building.

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, broadly the criteria are in two groups. One group would be the historical aspects, and the other group will be the architectural aspects. So there are two different bodies looking at these two aspects. The one looking at the architectural aspect is chaired by somebody from URA who is familiar with architecture and so on. The two different committees will award points for the two sets of criteria and, if they meet the cut-off point, the building will be considered for preservation.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan: In order to encourage and justify certain preserved buildings for further redevelopments, would PMB consider granting them certain incentives to further redevelop such shabby buildings, for instance, by giving greater plot ratio and greater height to encourage them to carry out redevelopment?

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry and the PMB are aware that there are costs involved in preserving these buildings. But I hope the building owners realise that these are important historical and national assets. As far as possible, we have tried to accommodate the requirements and the needs of the owners. For example, recently, during the opening of the MITA Building, I announced that we have come up with a new scheme known as Monuments Category II where we allow the building owners to redevelop the building so long as they preserve essential components of the building. It might be certain sections like the facade. This is following the approach taken by URA where they have conserved certain areas in Chinatown and Little India, so that the development potential of the building is preserved, the plot ratio is still allowed within the limits as set out in the Master Plan, and so on.

    There are two buildings which have been gazetted under this category and these are the MacDonald House where

Column: 1125

we had the bomb incident during Confrontation, and the other one is Cathay Building. In these two cases, there will be substantial redevelopment. We are only preserving the front of the MacDonald House and, for Cathay Building, we are only preserving the podium and the entrance. The Cathay Building will be redeveloped into a cineplex with seven or eight cinemas. It will be a very interesting and attractive redevelopment. But having said that, I am not so sure whether there is a need for further incentives. I think the Ministry has tried to preserve the values of the buildings in so far as to allow redevelopment within the limits of their potential under the Masterplan, but to go beyond that is something I am not sure whether Government will agree.

Reasons for regulation of TCM practitioners

    Sir, although Western medicine is the main form of healthcare in Singapore, Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) enjoys considerable popularity as a complementary form of healthcare. It has been estimated that about 45% of the population had ever consulted a TCM practitioner in the past. About 12% of the daily outpatient attendances opt to see TCM practitioners. Hence, TCM is a significant factor in the healthcare scene in Singapore.

    There is a similar trend in developed countries. In the West, complementary medicine, including TCM, has a significant following. Some Western countries now allow insurance claims or reimbursement for acupuncture treatment. Acupuncture and therapeutic massage (or tui na) have been popular among patients suffering from painful conditions. There is also the popular belief that TCM is milder and has fewer side effects, thus making it a preferred modality amongst older persons. As the population in Singapore ages, it is likely that there would be an increased demand for TCM treatment.

    The number of TCM practitioners in Singapore is also sizeable and it would probably increase in tandem with the demand for TCM treatment. A list published by the local TCM community in 1997 indicated that there were 1,807 TCM practitioners in Singapore. There is probably more now. The training and experience of TCM practitioners in Singapore vary. Some were self-taught. Some learned from peers or masters, while others graduated from TCM institutes.

    In July 1994, the Ministry of Health appointed a Committee to look into the regulation of TCM. The Committee recommended a phased approach, (ie a step-by-step approach) to the regulation of TCM practitioners in order to safeguard

Column: 1127

patients' interest and safety, as well as to enhance the standard of training and professionalism of TCM practitioners in Singapore.

    A phased approach is necessary, given the complexities of regulating TCM practitioners. Take the case of Hong Kong as an example. Although Article 138 of the Basic Law provided for the development of both Western and Chinese medicine, and there has been a Working Committee appointed since 1989 to promote, develop, and regulate TCM, the Chinese Medicine Ordinance was only enacted after 10 years in July 1999.

    To facilitate the regulatory process in Singapore, the Ministry of Health first encouraged the eight main local TCM organisations to form the Singapore Traditional Chinese Medicine Organisations Coordinating Committee (STCMOCC) in 1996. The STCMOCC serves as the coordinating body amongst the mainstream TCM community. It also acts as a channel of communication between the mainstream TCM community and the Ministry of Health.

    I must say that this arrangement has worked well. The formation of STCMOCC has led to the upgrading of the local TCM training course to a 6-year part-time diploma course in 1996. The STCMOCC has also worked out a listing of TCM practitioners in Singapore. That was how we knew that in 1997, there were 1,807 TCM practitioners in Singapore. In fact, this Bill was prepared with useful inputs from the STCMOCC. The Bill indeed has the support of the mainstream TCM community in Singapore.

Major provisions in the Bill

    Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me now to present the main provisions of the Bill. This Bill is an enabling legislation to allow the Minister to declare any type of practice of TCM for registration if he is of the opinion that it is in the public interest for that type of practice to be regulated. In other words, the Minister will decide which form of TCM practice to be regulated at which point of time. It will not be

Column: 1128

that, with the promulgation of this Act, every form of TCM practice will be regulated. Clause 14(1) of the Bill states that the Minister can regulate by order published in the Gazette. This is in line with the phased approach the Ministry of Health has been adopting.

    The Ministry of Health's intention is to start with regulating the acupuncturists, because acupuncture is an invasive procedure that carries risks of injury and infection. It is estimated that there are about 1,070 acupuncturists in Singapore. This will then be followed by the registration of TCM general practitioners in about 3 to 4 years' time, and the TCM herbal dispensers at a later date.

    This Bill takes reference from the existing medical- and health-related legislation such as the Medical Registration Act, the Dentists Act as well as the Nurses and Midwives Act. All these Acts are essentially based on self-regulation. This Bill provides for the establishment of a Traditional Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board appointed by the Minister to register TCM practitioners, to accredit TCM training courses and institutions, as well as to regulate the professional conduct and ethics of TCM practitioners. The Board will consist of 5 to 9 members, comprising peers from the TCM community, members of the medical profession, as well as representatives from the Ministry of Health.

    The Board can appoint Committees to which specific tasks are delegated. For example, the Board may appoint an Examinations Committee to set standards and to determine the content of the qualifying examinations for registration, as well as to oversee the organisation and conduct of the examinations. Also, the Board may appoint Investigation Committees to investigate complaints which may lead the Board to take disciplinary actions against practitioners.

    The TCM Practitioners Board will have disciplinary powers to deal with any registered TCM practitioner found guilty of professional misconduct, professional

    (a) caution or censure the practitioner;

    (b) impose a fine of not more than $10,000;

    (c) impose conditions on the practitioner's registration for a period of no more than three years;

    (d) suspend his or her registration for no more than three years; or

    (e) cancel his or her registration.

    Any practitioner who is aggrieved by the decision of the Board may appeal to the High Court within 30 days. A person whose registration has been cancelled can apply to the Board for restoration three years after the date of cancellation and not more than once in any period of 12 months. This is similar to the provisions made under the Medical Registration Act as well as the Dentists Act.

    To deter unlawful practice of TCM, the Bill provides for the imposition of penalties similar to the provisions of the Dentists Act. The Courts may fine the offender not more than $25,000 or imprison him for a term not exceeding sixmonths or both. In these southern countries of Europe, most childcare is still arranged privately (grandmothers take care of children while parents are at work and fathers do not look after children at all). There is this common expectation that parenting and household chores are the responsibility of the women. Sir, this is also the kind of stereotyped mindset that has been impinged on us for decades and is a major stumbling block, apart from other factors, for our present predicament. It is necessary for the socio-cultural attitude in Singapore to change with regard to gender acceptance. Men have to reconsider the role they must assume in the Singaporean households. Are they contributing to lighten the load of motherhood? Are fathers still clinging on to the cultures that foster the image of being not manly to do "women's work"? Are they having the "hands-off attitude" with regard to child-rearing and household chores? Sir, these old mindsets must go so that our womenfolk would become more willing to have more children knowing that they can have the support of their husbands.

Set up comprehensive formulation and implementation of policies including positive actions

    In some of the northern European countries, government handouts and support have helped ease the burden of raising children. Denmark has a "total fertility rate" of 1.7, which is relatively higher compared to, say, Italy with a TFR of 1.2. Sir, the level of childcare facilities and parental benefits seems to make a significant difference. Most countries on the southern rim of Europe, such as Italy and Spain, have some of the lowest TFR on the continent. The governments there provide much less child-related allowances than the Nordic countries. These northern countries have some of the highest fertility rates in Europe and this despite the fact that the proportion of women in their labour force is also among the highest. Childcare services are widely available and are subsidised up to 85% in some cases. In addition, the labour

Column: 1146

markets in the northern European countries are a lot more flexible than in the rest of the region. Part-time jobs, flexible working hours and tele-working are not uncommon. Financial support, in the form of birth and child allowances, is provided and, in certain cases, up to the time the child reaches adulthood. It would appear that the higher TFR resulted from a more conducive environment for adults to have children without giving up or losing their jobs. Labour force incentives are more important than monetary incentives in their case.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the announcement by Prime Minister Goh on baby bonuses, maternity leave for third child and setting up of a Ministerial Committee to study declining fertility is a good and welcome start.

    However, the incentives in monetary terms may make a bigger difference to those in the lower income families and not the better-off families who will look beyond the money incentives and look at childcare options, "stressful" education, career attainment and burden-free lifestyles. Additionally, administrative and workplace measures are the main concerns of many higher-income earners. Incentives on getting employers to provide practices that help workers harmonise work and family will be useful. Incentives that encourage companies to follow pro-family policies for their workers, especially for those with young families should be offered. Perhaps, for a start, we may look at the following:

    1. There must be a change in the mindset of those employers who prefer employees with no family commitments in terms of hiring and job promotion, and so on. Some incentives and campaigns are certainly needed, indeed, in this area.

    2. Incentives for big companies to set up their own childcare centres will ease many parents with the convenience of having their children at or near their workplace. This will benefit the working parents as they can conveniently deposit and pick up their children as well as visit them during tea breaks or at lunch time.

Column: 1147



    3. Our Government should consider providing free medical treatment for our pre-school children. The Singapore Government spends only about 1.1% of GDP on healthcare. This, Sir, is one of the lowest in a developed country where the usual average is about 5% to 7%. The healthcare burden on the people is high in Singapore. The public healthcare expenditure is 1.1% of GDP and the private healthcare expenditure is 2% of GDP or twice the amount spent by the Government. This contrasts significantly with that in England where the private share is only one sixth, in Australia where the private share is only half, and in Hong Kong and Malaysia where the ratio is roughly one to one. I feel it is, hence, reasonable to urge our Government to increase the spending on public healthcare for all Singaporean children.

    4. Housing is an important consideration to most people. The incentive given to help a young couple own a flat is welcome indeed. More help should be given to those couples who prefer to rent flats instead, for a variety of reasons. In my meet-the-people sessions, I have, many a time, found it necessary to sympathise with some constituents who needed rental flats badly due to overcrowding. Often, they were sharing two-room or three-room flats with other members of their families. Worse still, some had their own babies coming on the way.

Promote family-friendly work environment

    Sir, the United States has never tried shaping the birth rate or pushing any population policy, yet its fertility rate of 2.1 is the highest for the industrialised countries. Whilst immigration is an important contributory factor, a major difference is made by the US workforce that is more family-friendly now and is a source of support for working parents with children. The US has accommodated the need for two-earner families better than many European countries in various ways. Companies offer wide-ranging creative services from childcare to shoe repair, from paternity leave to a cafeteria that prepares take-home meals. The "Working

Column: 1148

Mother" magazine releases an annual ranking of the top 100 companies for working mums, and companies like to highlight that inclusion in this special list.

    Sir, a company's bottom-line need not be affected just because money is spent on family-friendly practices. After all, its money-making ability depends, to a large extent, on the well-being of its staff. The personal life of its employees can have a major impact on a company's performance. Employers who give their employees flexibility in balancing their work and personal lives will actually see an increase in profits. I read in the Straits Times that the First Tennessee Bank in the United States which had taken the family-friendly route, saw a 7% increase in customer retention and a US$106 million increase in profits, two years after doing so. Employees who have work-family conflicts are three times more likely to think about quitting their jobs. In contrast, employees who have supportive workplace have greater job satisfaction and are more willing to put in extra effort to help the company succeed. Sir, the Government, being the largest employer in Singapore, should be championing a family-friendly civil service and must take the lead in this area.

Facilitate women to participate in the workforce through flexible work arrangements like part-time work, flexi-time work, tele-work, and so on

    Flexibility in work arrangements must become more accepted by companies. The concept must be such that an employee may work non-normal hours so long as productivity is not compromised despite the unusual arrangements. I am glad that some of our Government Ministries have just started a pilot scheme of having extended public service hours that will result in staff having Saturdays off on a rotational basis. I hope this scheme will be extended to all public services in the near future.

    Thus, Mr Speaker, Sir, rotation between the staff to work certain time slots is possible and can enhance quality of life. With such flexi-time work, parents may

Column: 1149

then opt for certain "off-duty" time slots to coincide with their children's extra curricular activities, and so on. The opportunity for such interaction and contact with children is important; the prospect of more leisure time is an adjunct of a developed economy.

    Tele-working is well suited to women with young children. More such jobs should be made available to them. Employers must trust that work can also be done without staff at their seats within certain set hours.

    Part-time workers should be reimbursed on their CPF and medical benefits as for full-time workers. Also, many part-time workers do not get the same career advancement as for full-time workers. Contract workers, likewise, should have their lot enhanced. They should be provided adequate "safety net" benefits. Perhaps, the Government would look into these issues.

    Sir, as Singapore is a fast ageing society with a decreasing working to non-working ratio, the need for flexibility in work arrangement is destined to stay. The trend, in the not too distant future, will be for more people to require time off to look after their aged parents. Thus, pro-family policies at work should encompass the employee's responsibility towards their aged parents as well.

Improve our childcare facilities

    Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore is still short of childcare centres. MCDS is planning to increase the number of childcare centres by 25% to 58,000 within three years from the present 46,000 places. We should use this opportunity to better plan the childcare centres. And, besides numbers, better childcare centres should be provided for certified professionals and dedicated staff will give peace of mind to parents who now want professional care for their children. Enhancement of childcare facilities, such as more

Column: 1150

precinct-based childcare centres, developing "borrow-a-granny" and "share-a-maid" schemes, and so on, should be further facilitated.

    We should have the childcare centres evenly distributed throughout the island. In the newer HDB estates, where there are more young children, there is a need for such centres more urgently and in larger numbers. Cooperation between the Government, VWOs and private organisations is necessary to establish and allocate childcare centres. The aim should be to have the centres conveniently located in relation to either the home or the workplace. This, in effect, calls for employers to consider providing childcare centres at the workplace. In this respect, Sir, I would like to suggest that our Government help private organisations in terms of grants towards this cause. Realising that land cost will be a major burden for most operators, it may be worth looking at ways to alleviate this to ensure these centres remain affordable. Childcare centres should be provided for private dwellers as well. There are many young families buying and moving into new condominiums in areas with no childcare centres nearby.

    The number of childcare centres that cater to children below 18 months of age should be increased, as there is a dire shortage of them. At the moment, there are only three such centres catering to a mere 44 babies, against 40,000 annual births. I understand that it is difficult to run such centres and that this could be due to difficulties in hiring suitable care-givers, including nurses, greater responsibility with children that are young, intensive labour force in terms of carer-to-children ratio, and susceptibility of young children to sickness. MCDS should look to solve some of these difficulties and facilitate private organisations to run such centres more willingly. For a start, the enlistment of retired elderly to care for children may work.

    The Government should allow the agencies to provide part-time maids to fill certain situations. There are families who

Column: 1151

cannot afford to have full-time maids, but will benefit from several hours of help per week from part-time foreign domestic maids. Also ad-hoc child-minders, as and when circumstances arise, will be useful, for example, to mind children who are ill and cannot attend childcare centres and whose parents cannot take emergency leave and so on. Sir, the recent shutdown of childcare centres due to the hand, foot and mouth disease is a good example where this scheme would have served very well. This would be especially so for those parents who did not have relatives and friends who could mind their children for about 10 days. The inconvenience and economic loss would have been substantial as it involves about 140,000 children in 557 childcare centres and 440 kindergartens, if a majority of the parents cannot go to work.

Enhance Family Ties and Obligations

    There is a need to inspire the young with a deeper sense of individual responsibility towards the family. Basic social etiquette and interpersonal skills should be taught and promoted. This will lead to our young being better equipped with skills in handling boy-girl relationship, marriage and parental responsibility, and so on. Such "values" transmission can be done through teachers in schools, through some sort of parent-school-community partnership, through religious and community groups, and through the media. The Ministry of Education and Ministry of Community Development and Sports should look at these issues and be facilitative in this area.

    Traditionally, the father had been the sole breadwinner and the distant disciplinarian while mother was the nurturer and homemaker. In the present dual-income family, there should be a shift towards this perception of the roles of fathers and mothers. Parenting and homemaker tasks should be shared between spouses. The joy of bringing up children should be shared and experienced by both parents. Women whose husbands do not help out with childrearing and domestic chores are more stressed out. Research into marital satisfaction among Singaporean women

Column: 1152

showed a direct correlation between stress levels in women and the amount of help they get at home. Sir, many Singapore men want to be better fathers and husbands, but face constraints due to pressure at work and the lack of time. Therefore, it is timely to look towards a family-orientated society, with priority given to family needs. I am glad that our Government has recognised the partnership of child-bearing and homemaking by granting paternity leave. More effort should be spent in this area, such as further incentives and campaign to change the stereotyped mindset of many men regarding parenting and household responsibility. The Government should take the lead in changing the mindset of fathers and encouraging them to be equal partners in raising families.

    Strengthening family ties, better bonding with extended families and neighbourliness are areas worth cultivating. Community-based organisations should organise more activities in grassroots programmes to promote these virtues. Our CCC, CCMC, CDC and Town Councils can be active partners too. As the trend is for Singapore families to get smaller, extended families will not be the norm soon. And since they are all working, many will become too busy for interaction with families and friends. Such a trend, Sir, is bad and must be addressed. It is disturbing to know that quite a number of couples did not have anybody to fall back on to mind their children when childcare centres and kindergartens were closed during the recent hand, foot and mouth disease epidemic.

Address the Stress of Education

    The study by Dr Stella Quah of the National University of Singapore, on the Singapore Family, revealed that the greatest worry for about 45% of them came from the problems associated with their children's education. Singaporean parents have also frequently mentioned children's education as the contributory factor in opting for smaller families.

    Sir, I doubt many will fault our education system in terms of first-rate facilities,

Column: 1153

in terms of fantastic academic results, and even in terms of free and fair opportunities for all our children. The Government and educators spare no effort in trying to let our young have the best. We should all be glad. But we moan and we are disgruntled and dissatisfied. And we tell the world and allow the world to tell us how stressed we are from the education of our children.

    I contend, Sir, that some of the problems may have to do with our mindset on "success" and "competition for success". The "comparing" nature is something that has been encouraged in all of us because we have been trained to strive to be better than others, and there is no clear level when enough is enough. We are a success-orientated nation. It is only natural for parents to want success and the best for their children. Having the drive for success and for betterment is not a bad thing at all. But when such urge becomes excessive and begins to look like a survival prerequisite, then it is not good. Parents should be supportive and encourage their children in their education, and they should not push their children to beyond limits of the children's capabilities. This will cause unnecessary "stress" to themselves and their children. Mr Speaker, Sir, not all our children can go to university but the support should be to maximise each child's potential, whatever it may be. Success may not necessarily come from highest education alone. Note that our homegrown and remarkably successful businessman, Mr Sim Wong Hoo, graduated from the polytechnic and not the university. We do have to try to convince Singaporeans that success does not come from highest education alone. The Government must also show the example by not selecting and promoting people in the civil service with highest academic qualifications alone but also with other and different criteria.

    In 1998, 2,358 new cases of children aged below 18 were registered at Government psychiatric clinics. In almost 95% of the cases, the children were not mad; they were just stressed out. Half of

Column: 1154

these cases were children from primary schools, 35% from secondary schools and 15% were pre-schoolers. Stress at school was mentioned as one of the reasons for becoming depressed. My view is for teachers not to overload pupils unnecessarily with homework and tests. Syllabus needs to be revamped to make it less demanding so that the teacher can complete it and the students can understand what has been taught. For the above-average students, there is always the option for them to be given more challenging "add-ons".

    Is our school system so inadequate, Sir, that many parents turn to private tuition for their children? Many from the lower-income group cannot afford this and often feel pressured for being unable to give their children the "best" through private tuition. Personal coaching is often impossible because they hold full-time jobs. Moreover, much of the syllabus is beyond them anyway; this would be even more so for the lesser-educated parents. It will be a good idea if our schools can provide the same sort of tutorial classes after normal school hours, not for giving the children extra work but for helping them cope with their "homework".

    Insofar as helping parents with school-going kids balance work and family commitments, we may perhaps try matching work hours with school hours. Sir, since we are tending towards single-session schools, we can have the children stay back in the school to do their "homework" or have "remedials" while their parents are still at work. Another way to help parents, especially working parents, is to organise the extra-curricular pursuits, like learning drama, piano, ballet and so on, collectively in the schools after classes. This will save parents having to ferry their children to and from different places for these hobbies. I can see such a system helping Singaporean parents save much time, effort and money. Let us make our schools more holistic and comprehensive in nature.

    Whilst on the issue of schooling hours, I submit that the starting times are far too

Column: 1155

early at the moment. This is especially so if a child is not in a neighbourhood school, because the average journey from home can easily take 45 minutes. It is a common sight to see many school children at bus interchanges all over the island at around 6.20 in the morning. These children and their parents have to get up very early indeed. Many of them have less than the eight hours of sleep that is needed, especially for children. With the need to revise their schoolwork, do homework and projects, participate in ECAs, go for tuition, and so on, there is indeed a lot for the children to cope with in a day. On top of this, the parents have to rush to work, bring kids to the childcare centres or grandparents, etc, all within that same time-frame. Pre-school children or babies may have to be woken up, sometimes in the wee hours, to fit around their older siblings' schedules. Sir, we should aim for schooling hours to start at 8.30 in the morning. Most schools in the Western world start anytime from 8.30 to 9.00 in the morning.

    There has been too much emphasis on academic achievement and examination-based orientation in our school system. There is this concern that children are only "exam-smart" and, rather than a really well-rounded education, a lot of emphasis is given towards passing examinations and scoring A's. This will not hold well in the new economy. A well-rounded child may not be exam-smart, scoring straight A's and all, but may be able to think creatively and have a higher EQ. The Government has recognised that creativity is important and the old way of rote learning is out. But can we really grade critical and creative thinking? And, Sir, how do we transit into the new way? Are there existing policies that impede this transition?

    The criteria for the ranking of schools may have to be expanded to lessen the emphasis on academic achievements and grade scores. More weightage should be on other markers relevant to the present times; thus, ranking should take attainments in developing the potentials of students in information technology, sports and the arts into consideration. This will

Column: 1156

ease a lot of the pressures on students, parents and teachers.

    Many parents have expressed their concerns on streaming of children at Primary 4. They still perceive that EM1 students will have better peers and teachers, when, in fact, it may not be the case since the difference lies only in the mother tongue sessions that the students attend. Now that the requirements for mother tongue have been relaxed for university entry, parents should be reassured on the nature of streaming at Primary 4. It is unfortunate that, in any year, there is also some sort of banding of the students involved in Primary 4. However, banding students has been in practice for decades and is something parents have accepted. It would be worthwhile for the Ministry of Education and schools to put in more effort to better inform the parents on this issue to alleviate the stress associated with this.

    Having flexibility in varsity-entry criteria will ease the stress from many students and parents. Parents can then be at ease to allow their children to develop their own unique potential though it may not conform to the norm. Universities should not be too fixated on accepting students with a string of straight A's. Recently, a visiting molecular geneticist, Professor Tsui Lap Chee, said that he himself did not qualify for the university. He did brilliantly in biology, but merely passed his other subjects. Fortunately, the Department of Biology's head at the Chinese University of Hong Kong was so impressed with his biology grades that he persuaded the University to make an exception in his case. If the University had not bent the rules, he would not be where he is today - a world-renowned pioneer.

Enhance fertility, childbearing and family bonding

    There is a general tendency for the younger people in our workforce to put off courtship, marriage and childbearing to very much later in their lives. Often times, the reasons for this trend has to do with the ability to balance work commitments with other aspirations in life. There are

Column: 1157

unfortunate consequences when the pressure to succeed first at work leads to late marriage and childbearing. Hence, in our efforts to address the balance between work and family commitments, we have to look at alleviating some of the problems facing us concerning procreation.

    Sir, the following are some aspects worth our consideration.

Help the subfertile

    The chances that a fertile couple would need more than a year to produce a child doubles from 8% when the man was 25 years old to 15% when he was over 35. If our men do not make an effort to date, to get married, to go back early to spend time with their wives and their children, how do we achieve our ideal families? The prevalence of infertility in Singapore is about 10% of married couples, of which the men constitute about 30% to 40% of the contributory factor. The female is responsible for about 40% to 50%. The remaining 10% to 30% may be idiopathic or caused by contributing factors in both partners. Therefore, let us address this sad issue at both genders from the outset. These 10% of married couples often have to endure tremendous physical, emotional and financial hardships. Sir, I feel that these couples should be helped as fertility medical treatment can be time-consuming and very expensive. The Medisave withdrawal limit for the most costly procedure, intro-vitro fertilisation (IVF), should be reviewed. The current withdrawal limit of $2,000 per treatment cycle up to a maximum of three cycles per patient for a procedure costing near $10,000 per treatment cycle is far too low. Our adoption procedure should be made less onerous to enable couples to adopt children. There are many cases where, despite exhaustive treatment, couples may still not be able to conceive. For them, adoption is an option and they should be assisted.

Encourage earlier childbearing

    Publicity and promotion of early childbearing age should be done extensively

Column: 1158

to educate the public on the medical disadvantages of pregnancy in older women. In Singapore, 16.8% of pregnancies involve older women. This figure far exceeds the developed world's average of 8%. Here, an average of 17 out of every 100 women who give birth is above the age of 35. Pregnancy in older women carries increased risks for mums and babes. These include miscarriages, pregnancy complications and complicated deliveries. There is also a higher risk for chromosomal abnormalities, the most common one being Down's syndrome. For women aged 25 and below, the chances are one in 800, but by the age of 40, the rate increases to one in 63.

Enhanced pro-family practices

    Enhancing practices that will promote family unity and procreation is necessary. For instance, the option for mothers to have extended unpaid maternity leave, whilst available, is not widely accepted. This common practice in both the public and private sectors in the western countries and in Australia allows for working mothers to extend their maternity leave by up to six months. Mothers get to spend more time with their babies during the post-delivery period, a time which is crucial for mother-baby bonding and is certainly a pro-family ideal.

Expand avenues for courtship and marriage

    One in three Singapore adults in their early 30s is still single. And 16.5% of them remain single well into their 40s, compared to just one in 10 in 1990. According to the

2000    Census, 27% of men in their late 30s were unmarried, while 18.5% of women in this age group were single. Unlike single women, many of whom are graduates, two-fifths of the over 77,000 single men above 35 have secondary education or less.

    The Social Development Unit (SDU) was set up in 1984 by the People's Association to promote marriage among graduates. Since then, 21,400 SDU members have got married. The Social Development Service (SDS) was set up

Column: 1159

in 1985 to create opportunities for non-university graduates. Since then, 87,000 SDS members had married. SDU and SDS have done well and should be further supported to expand their roles to achieve higher targets. In today's context of busy schedules and less time to meet and to court, more avenues for people to interact are essential.

    One in five single British men and women is turning to dating agencies and personal advertisements to start relationship, confirming a trend researchers have found that modern lifestyle and job demands are killing traditional courtship. Facilitating and providing avenues for young people to come together in the schools, polytechnics, universities and community centres and so on will give them the opportunity to intermingle with peers within their cohorts. This opportunity may not be there once they start their working life. Credible websites run by Government agencies or reputable private organisations that ensure correct and certified data of individuals will be useful. I believe that, in the IT era, this channel will prove to be the preferred choice for many of our IT-savvy and busy young people to acquaint and befriend each other.

    The Government, Sir, should spearhead more social-support factors. I am of the opinion that encouraging marriages with financial enticements would not be a good idea. This is in contrast with the case of encouraging couples to have bigger families with financial incentives. Parents and young people should abandon the mindset that students should not court until they have graduated and are established in their careers because by then, it becomes increasingly difficult to meet and to start courting. Young people would be well-advised to be responsible adults who are accountable in relationship, responsible towards each other and sensible in pursuing studies simultaneously with a relationship without jeopardizing one for the other.

    To conclude, Sir, no Government can dictate people to get married or to have

Column: 1160

more children. Our Government, however, can facilitate the people to fulfill their family wishes and one of the best ways to do this is through helping them to harmonise work and family. While the Government can make it more conducive for people to get married and have bigger families, the eventual result rests on the expectations of parents, their ability to juggle and manage time better.

    Sir, the crux of the whole issue and the solution lies, ultimately, in the hands of all Singaporeans themselves. They must have the correct attitude towards what they want in life. They must believe that fulfilment in life depends on a balance between their work responsibilities and their family needs rather than a compromise on one for the other. This involves a major change in mindset of Singaporeans and this House needs to urge the Government for a positive move to achieve such a change.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, thank you for this opportunity to speak on this topic.

    Sir, our children are the future of the nation. They are nurtured in the fold of the family. The family is a pillar of the stability of the nation. There is thus no question of the importance of strong families to the future of Singapore. Many factors make for a happy family. Government policies impinge on the family. I am delighted to note that over the years, the Government has made visible efforts to implement family supportive policies. More can be done and I am confident that more will be done.

    Workers from happy families are more productive and I urge all employers to make the effort to make the workplace an environment friendly to the family. As an employer, the Government has been responsive to the needs of the family, introducing family-friendly practices and facilities. Many companies have also put in efforts and funds to do so. They are

Column: 1161

good examples to follow. I urge the employers to do more and others who have not done so to consider and implement family-friendly practices.

    Sir, family members, especially parents, also have a major role in creating a happy family environment. I want to add on to a point that Dr Lily Neo raised in her address - stress caused by the education system. I believe that hard work is necessary for success. Children have worked hard for their success. There is no alternative even for those naturally endowed. We should not ask the Ministry of Education to merely make our education system easier for our student for his own sake. MOE has been reviewing the system to make our system better able to meet the needs of our future in the new economy. MOE has adapted our system to be performance-based, each student to work at his or her own pace and capability. We should espouse instead the philosophy of being the best we can be. Hence, I urge parents not to pressurize their children beyond their capabilities. They should not have unrealistic expectation of them, making unrealistic demand on their capability and performance. Parents should thus encourage their children to do their best. We should allow our children their time, their space so that they can have their childhood.

    Sir, if every party plays his, her or its part in promoting the welfare of the family, I am sure the quality of family life for our citizens will improve.

    I support the motion.

    Dr Jennifer Lee: Sir, I rise to support the motion standing in the name of the Member for Kreta Ayer-Tanglin GRC on family-friendly work practices.

    Since the Prime Minister's speech here in this Chamber in October one year ago, on his concern that Singaporeans are not reproducing ourselves, increasing attention has been turned to the subject, once again, of persuading Singaporeans

Column: 1162

to increase their productivity from the population perspective. Intimately intertwined in the ensuing discussions and debate is the subject of the family, and of the stresses on our current day Singaporean families, which surely impacts on our young couples' decisions on whether to start a family and, in fact, on the size of the family to have.

    We have seen considerable activity over this period with the formation of the Working Committee on Marriage and Procreation, involving an impressive panel of Permanent Secretaries, the announcement of a Ministerial Committee to be led by the Minister without Portfolio, Mr Lim Boon Heng, the establishment of a Work-Life Unit by MCDS, and yet another committee on Public Education on the Family, chaired by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary of MCDS. In between, there has been a seminar to discuss the preliminary report of the Committee on the Family, workshops conducted by invited consultants on Work-Life Balance, and the Family Friendly Awards, a tripartite initiative of SNEF, MCDS and NTUC.

    All this energy and enthusiasm is certainly a good start, but the concern is that this flurry of activity gets translated into real, substantial and sustained effort, policy reviews and initiatives and programmes for both the immediate and the long term.

    The current Government attention on family-friendly and pro-family work practices, policies and programmes to support and strengthen the family is, to a large extent, driven by the baby agenda. But, in fact, these practices, policies and programmes are important for far more than just promoting the production of babies.

    Strengthening the family is intrinsically important in itself, especially as we have always held the family to be the basic building block of our society. Even more so in the face of the challenges of the accelerating pace of our modern working environment, coupled with the influences

Column: 1163

that our youngsters are now open to with the easy accessibility of information.

    Strengthening existing families is important, even if all our efforts do not result in one more couple deciding to have one more baby. And, indeed, helping Singaporeans maintain a balance between their work and family responsibilities is an intrinsic and essential factor in achieving the quality of life that we all aspire to as citizens contributing to a first-world economy.

    In that same speech last October, the Prime Minister spoke of our twin goals of having both a first-world economy and a world-class home. He observed that the goal of a first-world economy was easier to achieve than that of a world- class home, which involves many intangibles and cannot be measured simply by hardware and physical infrastructure.

This policy needs to be reviewed if we want to encourage families to play together. Swimming pools provide good opportunities for the whole family to keep fit as well as to have fun together.

However, if we look at it from the pro-family as well as the healthy lifestyle perspectives, the benefits to be gained should outweigh the costs in the long run. Besides, the smaller swimming complex can be built near a cluster of schools and be utilised for extra-curricular activities.

    Finally, I wish that, as a good start, the Government will consider forming a

Column: 1183

working committee to study the physical infrastructure needs for building and strengthening family bonding within our communities. This should send a clear signal to all citizens that the Government is actively seeking ways to improve the quality of life of all Singaporeans by taking the positive step towards fulfilling its commitment to S21.

    Mr Simon Tay: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for allowing me to join the debate.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I had not planned to join this debate, and I may not have done so if this morning my 3-year-old son had not woken me and asked me to play with him. I did so until 9.30 and then got to the office only at 10. I may not have joined this debate also if my wife did not tell me, when we were walking at 7.00 am, that she wished we had a reliable part-time domestic help instead of a full-time foreign worker we do have.
