    Sir, I think we are all in this House in favour of families and family-friendly practices. What I am concerned about is that our support becomes merely convention - stated but not practised - that we replace, in this sense, motherhood statements with family-hood statements.

    When I first think of family-friendly practices, I do of course think of the women - the wives and mothers among us. Too many have to make a choice between a job they enjoy and their children whom they also enjoy. And this is a beggar's choice. They should have more options than this. Losing women from the workplace is a loss not only to the economy but also for the women themselves. Many enjoy aspects of work and life outside the house, and this is a part of what they want for themselves in their

Column: 1184

training, in their view of their own self-esteem. And, of course, they love their children. But this is a great sacrifice that need not always be made and may not always be best.

    But while they are important, this debate about families should look beyond women as wives and mothers. If we do not, there is a danger that when we think of the family, we assume and cater only to what some think of as the ideal family, ie, husband and wife, children - two or more, please - with the assumption of a maid and perhaps a helpful and active grandmother.

    From this perspective, Sir, it is too easy to think of family-friendly practices as being primarily and perhaps only for women as wives and mothers. While this is the ideal that some in our society presently uphold, we have to look beyond this if we are truly to be family-friendly.

    The idea of a family after all, as sociologists tell us, is changeable over time, culture and space. In Singapore in a past generation, extended families were the norm. There were also families which involved more than one wife, more than one mother. In other countries today, while the nuclear family is the norm, the exact arrangements of who takes care of the children may differ from what we in Singapore think of as normal. We do not have to change our social norms. But we do need to show true flexibility if we are to be truly friendly to the family. In this context, I put forward three suggestions.

    The first is on fathers. I must confess an interest here. I think we must not be patriarchal. Even if most Singaporeans still believe that the woman must be the one who is the primary care-giver to the family, we must be flexible enough to give men the option. We should not design the workplace so that men work too long and too hard without any choice, while women join, inevitably, a sort of slow track or, as in Japan, have the primary role in the workplace as tea ladies. A few men may want to become house-husbands and the primary care-giver to the children. More

Column: 1185

men may wish to take on a larger share of the family duties while still keeping the wife in the primary driver-seat. And even if the norm is otherwise, our system must be flexible enough to allow for this.

    Second, single mothers. Our Government has been reluctant to acknowledge singles and, especially, single parents. I understand that many do not wish this to be the norm. Accordingly, some incentives should go only for couples. However, we should not go too far in this. If one takes the idea of being a single parent seriously and no one takes it lightly, the pressures of money, time and responsibility are very great, and I think all Singaporeans recognise this. If, despite all these, a Singaporean does make that decision, I think we have to have a system that supports and allows that decision.

    The third suggestion is on dependence on the domestic maid or helper. I think, Sir, there is a time and a need to seriously look at the provision of part-time domestic help, childcare centres and other facilities that will enable the nuclear family, ie, the mother and the father, to do more for themselves and more for their children. There need, in other words, to be alternatives to the full-time foreign maid as the primary care-giver. This is important for privacy and quality family time; this is important to have parents recognise a greater role in the care of their own children. There is not much point in providing more swimming pools or more play centres if all we see there are maids with children, and parents at the workplace or the shopping centres. We need, in a sense, to ask the Ministry of Manpower to help promote and professionalise part-time housekeeping services by Singaporeans for Singaporean families and, perhaps, to have a match-making service for this.

    I think it was Tolstoy or some other Russian writer who said that all happy families are the same while every unhappy family has unique cause and character. In today's world, I beg to

Column: 1186

disagree. In the face of so many pressures in the workplace in competition between companies to get ahead, I think it is each happy family now that is unique. Our system has to be flexible enough, therefore, to acknowledge and support each and every family in its effort to be unique and to be happy.

    The Minister without Portfolio (Mr Lim Boon Heng): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank Dr Lily Neo for her comprehensive survey of issues relating to the family, especially to raising our fertility rate. I wish also to thank all those who spoke, with great spirit in some cases, and gave their views and suggestions.

    Most of the concerns raised are real ones, shared by the Government. This is the reason why the Prime Minister has asked me and two of my Cabinet colleagues, Messrs Lim Hng Kiang and Abdullah Tarmugi, to form the Ministerial Committee on Marriage and Procreation to look into these concerns. The fact that the Prime Minister himself raised the subject and spoke of the joys of a family at the National Day Rally, shows that the Government is not just concerned with economic achievements but also with our social achievements. Dr Lee, I feel, misinterpreted the Prime Minister's statement. The Prime Minister acknowledges that it is far harder to measure social development, not that we are clinging to the old economic ones. Many of Dr Neo's proposals and those of the other speakers have actually either been implemented, are being implemented, or are currently being seriously considered.

    I will now reply to some of the more specific points that they have raised. First, I will start with the physical ones that Dr Teo Ho Pin has suggested. I would like him to expand on his ideas. But it is not necessary to form yet another ministerial committee or committee of Parliament to do it. In the spirit of S21, Dr Teo and like-minded Members of Parliament, as well as like-minded members of the public, can get together, do a study and present a comprehensive report. That report could

Column: 1187

be submitted to the Ministerial Committee on Marriage and Procreation or, if he feels that he could do so directly with the Minister for National Development, he is also free to do so. This is what we mean when we talk about participation by the public.

    Dr Neo has urged that there be a comprehensive approach to formulating and implementing policies to address the issue of falling fertility. We totally agree with her. Therefore, when the Government announced the package of measures to encourage marriage and procreation recently, we stressed the need to create a total environment conducive to couples marrying and having more children. Here, I would like to reiterate to Mr Simon Tay that the Government's objective is to have couples marrying and having more children within the institution of marriage. So it is not the role of the Government to promote single parenthood. Besides monetary incentives like the Baby Bonus Scheme, the measures included promoting pro-family work practices, increasing the supply of quality childcare centres, easier home ownership for young couples, public education and creating socialising opportunities for the young.

    A key measure is public education. Hence, a Public Education Committee (PEC) on the Family chaired by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Community Development and Sports, Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon, has been formed. The PEC will look into a number of the proposals that Dr Neo has raised, such as changing the mindset of employers who prefer employees with no family commitments, encouraging earlier childbearing and role-sharing, and expanding the avenues for young people to socialise. I do not need to elaborate on this as Dr Neo, being a member of the PEC, will be familiar with its work. I also note that Dr Vasoo and Dr Jennifer Lee are also members of this Committee. We hope that Dr Neo and these other members of the Committee would spare no effort in this important task of changing mindsets.

    There are, of course, already many existing pro-family policies. We have, for

Column: 1188

example, been advocating that the responsibility of parenthood does not lie solely with the women and fathers must share their responsibilities in bringing up their children. The Prime Minister reiterated this when he announced the paternity leave scheme in the civil service in August this year. It may not be very much of a fringe benefit in terms of cost but it is a very strong signal to the public at large that the fathers also have a role to play. MCDS has also been organising and supporting seminars on fathering to highlight the importance of fatherhood.

    Another example is our pro-family public housing. There are rental schemes in place for young couples setting up homes for the first time. Those who book a new flat still under construction under the Registration for Flat System (RFS) or who have been in the queue for at least three months awaiting selection of a flat can apply to rent a three-room flat under the Transitional Rental Housing Scheme. For low income couples, they could apply under the Public Rental Housing Scheme to rent a one-room or two-room flat from HDB, or the Rent and Purchase Scheme which allows them to first rent a three-room flat and buy over the flat subsequently when their financial situation improves.

    The People's Association has also been encouraging community-based organisations to conduct more grassroots programmes to strengthen family ties and neighbourliness. Activities range from family day activities to festive celebrations involving families. And I hope that all advisers will review the activities of their grassroots organisations and make sure that they are better focused and therefore more effective in strengthening family bonds. The work is not that of just the Government and policies. The work has to be done on the ground and I hope, through the advisers, that more can be done.

    The civil service has also implemented several family-friendly initiatives. Apart from the paid marriage and paternity leave that were implemented from 1st October this year, it has allowed individual

Column: 1189

ministries and departments to arrange flexi-work arrangements as long as there is no loss of productivity and lapse in service standards to the public. These are in addition to many other pro-family policies introduced much earlier, for example, no-pay leave for childcare, part-time employment for working mothers and sick childcare leave.

    Promoting family-friendly practices in private sector companies is a key strategic focus for both the Ministry of Community Development and Sports and the Ministry of Manpower. This is intended not just to improve family life but also work life. Efforts to encourage employers to adopt family-friendly work practices were first initiated by the then Ministry of Community Development and its people sector-led Committee on the Family. One of the first major initiatives was the launch of the Family Friendly Firm Award in 1998. This was introduced together with the Ministry of Manpower, the Singapore National Employers Federation and the National Trades Union Congress. The award aims to recognise companies for their pro-family efforts and encourage them to introduce and promote innovative pro-family practices for their employees.

    The Government is well aware of the increasing struggles for families in coping with a fast-paced knowledge-based economy. This year, both Prime Minister Goh and Deputy Prime Minister BG Lee have emphasised the need to have pro-family workplaces. This is particularly so as the dual income families become the norm and working hours become longer in a 24 x 7 economy. But let us pause and think. The 24 x 7 economy does not necessarily mean that each person has to work longer hours in a week. It is how we roster people at work and how smartly they work that is important, not the number of hours that they spend at work. And this is the focus which all employers should bear in mind when they devise pro-family practices. It will make a mockery of the concept of productivity if getting more work done means getting the workers to work longer hours.

Column: 1190



    As mentioned by Dr Neo, many of the organisations in the United States of America have offered family-friendly work practices believing that being family-friendly makes good business sense. This is despite their government's negligible role in promoting family-friendly programmes. In fact, these companies no longer talk about work-family balance because the word "balance" seems to suggest a zero sum game. Instead, they talk about work-life effectiveness as they strongly believe that employees with strong personal and family ties would be more effective and motivated at work. Family and work are not necessarily at odds with each other. This represents a paradigm shift and reflects a holistic approach. European companies too have adopted family-friendly practices.

    We want our local companies to emulate these companies. We agree that employers should, as far as possible, implement flexi-work arrangements to help Singaporeans with family responsibilities to participate in the workforce. This is particularly so with the availability of IT. Our existing employment laws are already flexible in allowing flexi-work arrangements. What is needed are creative solutions by human resource managers. Our laws also ensure that workers employed on a part-time basis can enjoy pro-rated employment benefits such as medical leave. Employers are also required to contribute to the Central Provident Fund even if the employee is working part-time. Nevertheless, the Ministry of Manpower is reviewing the Employment Act to ensure that they continue to meet the needs of business and employees. And those employers who want to re-design their working hours and practices and who encounter some problems with our legislation would be encouraged to bring them up with the Ministry of Manpower so that they can be taken into account when the Employment Act is reviewed.

    We would also like to point out that the paid maternity leave in our Employment Act for up to two children and the additional grants for the second and third child are in fact more favourable and family-friendly as compared to a number

Column: 1191

of other countries including Australia, New Zealand and some states in the United States of America which do not even require employers to pay for such leave as a statutory benefit. Such benefits in these countries are subject to negotiations between the employer and employee concerned. The point I want to put across to Members is: let us look at the total package, not just on specific measures that are available in any country. We have to look at the total package and see how those incentives work before we say that we should adopt them.

    Implementing family-friendly work practices requires much work to be done in changing our employers' mindsets and that is why the Ministry of Community Development and Sports set up a Work-Life Unit in September this year to promote family-friendly work practices. The Ministry of Manpower itself has also set up the Human Resource Promotion Section in 1999 to promote good human resource (HR) practices. These measures reflect our commitment to bringing about a workplace culture change.

    As mentioned by Dr Lee, MCDS engaged two leading American work-life consultants to conduct awareness seminars and training workshops for HR managers as well as provide consultancy to companies in Singapore. The response to these events was overwhelming. Numerous companies have already approached the Work-Life Unit to give sharing sessions on work-life strategies and to provide more information and advice. So an encouraging ground swell has started to build up.

    Another initiative which the Ministries are working on would be the compilation of actual pro-family practices that work, for example, K K Hospital, Changi Hospital, ST Aerospace and others, to show other employers what can be done and we will need to provide greater publicity for these measures that work.

    Next, I turn to childcare facilities. Dr Vasoo has asked for a review of childcare subsidies. We can assure Dr Vasoo that the subsidies will be reviewed periodically

Column: 1192

to ensure that they keep pace with the times. Dr Neo asked for better distribution of childcare centres. Childcare centres in private residential areas are set up by private operators and, as in any commercial enterprise, the numbers are determined by the viability of the project. In new HDB estates, MCDS plans ahead of demand through regular meetings with HDB based on the number of dwelling units for the estate. For older HDB estates, we increase the number of centres in high demand areas. MCDS works closely with HDB so that childcare premises are conveniently sited together with the housing blocks. MCDS will be delegating the local planning of childcare centres to Community Development Councils (CDCs), which will better enable them to gauge and respond to local demand. Here, Members of Parliament who are members of CDCs can expect to play a greater role at the local area. For a start, this will take place starting with Marine Parade and Tanjong Pagar CDCs. MCDS will continue to manage demand and supply at the national level and ensure that acceptable standards are met.

    Besides promoting the setting up of childcare centres in private residential areas, we also encourage childcare centres in condominiums. URA levies development charges at the residential rate instead of commercial rate for childcare centres in condominiums. URA has also lifted restrictions requiring such centres to serve residents only.

    Some financial support and incentives are provided to employers who set up childcare centres as an employee benefit. These include capital grants for furnishing and equipping new centres and various tax incentives. We can review these incentives to see whether they are adequate and up them if they are not, although we should note that our studies show a low demand for workplace childcare centres overall. This is the more important factor than plot ratios that Dr Lee, Mrs Lim Hwee Hua and Dr Vasoo had mentioned. A critical mass is necessary for a childcare centre to be viable, and that has been the experience of NTUC Childcare for which I have some knowledge. You must have a

Column: 1193

critical mass of children using a centre for that centre to be economically viable. As a rule of thumb, it is now above 100 children per centre. So, there have been childcare centres at workplaces run by NTUC Childcare contracted by the employers, but the number of children had been too few for the centres to be viable and, unfortunately, they had to close down. I think if we wish to have more such centres set up where the parents work, a viable centre would be one that does not specifically serve one employer only, and has to serve a number of employers, so that we can get a critical mass of children using that centre to make the cost within reason. This is something which private operators can examine and if there are impediments to the setting up of such centres, please let us know and, where possible, the obstacles can be removed.

    MCDS has also studied the obstacles to the development of childcare centres catering to children below 18 months. We are mindful of the fact that many child experts agree that the first few years of a child's life are important for parent to child bonding, and that infants are best cared for at home by their mothers or relatives. And indeed surveys also show that that is the preference of the parents themselves. Hence, we should put more emphasis on support for home care, such as family-friendly employment practices and also encourage the extended family. However, if dual income families have no other alternatives to care for their infants, we have to promote other care arrangements. One of the measures taken recently was to revise the requirement for infant care centres to have at least one paediatric-trained nurse to one state approved nurse. This does not compromise standards. In fact, when we have trained sufficient early childhood personnel specialising in infant care, the requirement to have a nurse can be removed altogether. The whole purpose is, of course, to bring down the cost of operating such centres.

    As for allowing part-time employment of foreign domestic workers, the Ministry of Manpower is hesitant to introduce such

Column: 1194

an option. Currently, there are more than 100,000 foreign domestic workers in Singapore. This number has doubled in the last 10 years. Allowing households access to part-time foreign domestic workers may greatly increase their numbers, as households without foreign domestic workers could turn to them. This could increase our reliance on foreign labour and could have adverse social consequences. There would also be concerns over the question of responsibility of looking after the welfare and accommodation of these workers. They may be exploited or abused. And allowing foreign domestic workers to work part-time will stunt the emergence of a strong domestic service sector. So let us look at the need and examine how other countries achieve higher female labour force participation rates than us without relying on foreign domestic workers. I think this is an issue which we have not examined to any depth. Why are the Nordic countries, as Dr Lily Neo says, reflecting a higher fertility rate than us, and yet in those Nordic countries they do not have a heavy reliance on foreign domestic maids? Maybe there are things that they can teach us. And I think one of the possibilities is the availability of services using local domestic workers rather than foreign domestic workers.

    Next, on stress in education. Dr Neo has made a number of proposals to fine tune our education system. She talked about homework overload. I would like to assure her that the Ministry of Education has a differentiated curriculum to develop each child to his or her potential. However, sometimes the expectations and aspirations of parents come into play, and these have direct impact on their children's stress level. Our message to these parents is that they should not stress the child beyond what he or she is capable of. Instead, we should look at the total development, not just the academic achievements of the child. What is already in the school curriculum is sufficient. It is not necessary to overload the child with a lot of other extra-curricular activities. So it is the responsibility of the parents to ensure that there is no such overload.

Column: 1195



    As for providing tutorial classes after school hours, I understand that the schools today have various programmes and activities to cater to those who need help with their school work.

    On schools starting later and allowing facilities to be used by students throughout the day, the Ministry of Education has implemented single session programmes in all secondary schools this year. Hence, these schools have the flexibility to rearrange their formal curriculum hours to accommodate the needs of their pupils by starting their day later. Co-curricular activities, pastoral care and other programmes can also be organised after class by the students, and also with the support of the parents. Primary schools will have constraints as they run double session programmes now. However, this too is being reviewed.

    The Ministry of Education also agrees that children should not only be exam-smart. Hence, the Ministry of Education implemented the Thinking Skills programme in all secondary schools in 1999, to encourage students to think critically and creatively. It has also introduced Inter-disciplinary Project Work to all schools and have a few challenging "thinking questions" in their examinations. And, recently, that caused a little bit of uproar with respect to the PSLE.

    Schools are also ranked on both academic and non-academic achievements. The Ministry of Education has also adopted the school excellence model for all schools this year to broaden the scope of the way schools are appraised. Linked to this is an award system that recognises talents and abilities in non-academic spheres.

    The universities will also implement a new admission system in the year 2003, moving away from a sole reliance on 'A' levels towards a more holistic evaluation of a person's potential to benefit from university education. Hence, performance in a reasoning test, project work and co-curricular activities will be considered.

    Having said all that, let me take a step back and ask all of us to assess our

Column: 1196

education system. International studies have shown that we have a good system. I hope that the Public Education Committee will address this and bring home this point to all parents, so that there is less stress come school registration time. It is not necessary to get into the so-called list of top schools.

    As for stress on academic results, let me reassure Members of the House that the public service does not promote on the basis of examination results. The public service promotes on the basis of performance, the result of a performance appraisal which the public service does, and not because of what kind of examination results that person has had in school or at university. And it would be an exaggeration, to put it mildly, to describe our system as elitist. We should not confuse meritocracy with elitism.

    Next, subsidising health care for children. Dr Neo has suggested providing free medical treatment for our pre-school children. Currently, the Government is already providing a national childhood immunisation programme and the development screening programme which monitors the growth and development of infants and pre-school children free of charge at our polyclinics. For acute care, our healthcare finance policy stresses personal responsibility for maintaining good health. Parents should look after the health of their children. For children who fall sick and seek treatment in our heavily subsidised polyclinics and public hospitals, the parents have to pay only part of the cost of the medical service consumed. The principle of co-payment is necessary to avoid the pitfall of "free" medical services stimulating insatiable demand, and to keep the cost of basic health care affordable. Currently, our children are subsidised at 75% at the polyclinics and between 65% and 80% in Class B2 or C wards. Our children will never be denied access to basic medical care because their parents are in financial difficulties as the parents can apply for Medifund assistance or waiver of fees.

    As to the point about Government expenditure on health care, we must bear

Column: 1197

in mind that higher Government expenditure on health care is often related to higher tax rates. So it is one or the other.

    With regard to liberalising the use of Medisave for assisted conception procedures (ACP), the Ministry of Health has received feedback from the public regarding the inadequacy of the current Medisave withdrawal limits imposed on ACP. It is currently reviewing the Medisave withdrawal limits.

    By and large, there are also few procedural impediments to childless couples adopting babies. When social investigations are conducted, they serve to safeguard the interests and well-being of the child to be adopted. The primary problem is the lack of babies, especially local ones, available for adoption.

    Foreign adoptions require certain safeguards and checks to ensure that the adoptive parents see through their responsibility of raising the child. We do not want situations where parents give up their adopted child later because of difficulties in the relationship. Nonetheless, MCDS and other departments involved will continue to look into facilitating foreign adoption.

    Much of what we have discussed are on social infrastructure and the soft aspects of the issues, and the building up of social capital in our society. It is the subject of social capital which is completely relevant to the subject in hand for which we have not fully explored. We will have to understand not only the work pressures but other factors at work that inhibit couples from having children. Here, I think we are going into a much larger area for which we have as yet little good knowledge. But we should continue to examine those factors and address them wherever we can.

    With family-friendly workplaces and family-friendly environment and our continual drive in putting forward pro-family policies, programmes, services and

Column: 1198

messages, I am confident that we can become an even more family-oriented society. I am sure that the energies demonstrated by Members of this House will translate into more babies and stronger families.

    Dr Lily Neo: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank Mr Lim Boon Heng for his favourable and positive responses. I would also like to express my gratitude to all my colleagues - Dr Vasoo, Mrs Lim Hwee Hua, Dr Tan Boon Wan, Dr Teo Ho Pin, Mr Yeo Guat Kwang, Dr Jennifer Lee and Mr Simon Tay - who have participated in this debate. They have raised many good suggestions and unique perspectives that make this debate interesting and fruitful.

    On child care centres, Mr Lim Boon Heng said that their studies showed a low demand for work-place child care centres overall.     Sir, I can understand that private organisations would always consider the cost of providing child care centres. Mr Lim Boon Heng has mentioned about a critical mass for child care centres to be economically viable. However, the challenge is to re-emphasise that money spent on family-friendly practices is a draw for the company's performance and attractiveness. Steps taken by the Government to re-visit and review facilities in terms of grants, tax incentives and set up such centres will endorse this practice. Echoing Dr Jennifer Lee, Dr Vasoo and Mrs Lim Hwee Hua, I would like to suggest that the Ministry of National Development waive development charges for building child care centres at workplaces and favourably treating this as in the category of community service by our Government.

Column: 1199

by starting their day later. It seems, however, that principals have not taken the initiative to start later. I doubt if it is really in the interest of the students that no change in the start-times has been made, especially for the single-session schools. I therefore feel that there is a need for positive directive from the Ministry of Education on this, especially for single-session schools.

    (1) The opportunity for more births;

    (2) Infertile couples' desperation for a child of their own;

    and

    (3) Such couples are usually young and can build up their Medisave savings for many more years.

    On the difficulty for young couples to rent HDB flats, Mr Lim Boon Heng mentioned existing schemes available to young couples.     Sir, our existing HDB rental policy dashes our hope of changing the mindset of our young who are postponing marriage and starting family until they have succeeded in their careers or have bought their own homes. Our policy should not be hampering or contradictory in nature. Therefore, if young couples are not prepared to buy HDB homes for whatever reasons, they should not be denied the rental of HDB flats.

    The Minister gave several reasons against allowing part-time foreign maids.

Column: 1200

Sir, I would like to appeal for a reconsideration with the following viewpoints:

    (a) Allowing part-time foreign maids will create additional demand. This may not necessarily be so as those who have full-time foreign maids may then opt for part-time ones to save cost or to have more privacy and so on. In fact, as mentioned by Mr Simon Tay earlier, his wife is one of those who prefers part-time maid.

    (b) Accommodation for part-time maids will be a concern. This can be overcome by allowing only those agents that can provide accommodation getting the licence to recruit. The number of maids that will be approved will depend on the space or accommodation available for them.

    (c) Issue of exploitation of maids and illegals working in other sectors. Here, the agents again have to be made accountable for some code of practice to address this problem. Sir, deterrent measures can be put in place to deal with errant agents.

    (e) Stunting the emergence of a strong domestic service sector. Sir, this is not valid because Singaporeans would not take such jobs which are considered lowly.

    Mr Lim Boon Heng has said that many European country families do not need maids. I would like to reiterate that these countries have good government and social support as well as conducive work environment that are pro-family. If we can match them one day in the near future, probably Singaporean families may not need maids too.

    In conclusion, I would say that social conditions change and it is necessary therefore that policies get adjusted accordingly to suit the needs of the time. Even if difficulties abound, the desired outcome must be sought. As I have said
